div1.p: On or about the 16th of February last, the Captain of the French gunboat "Marabout" acting under orders, destroyed by setting them on fire, certain establishments of the African natives on the Gabon River.

One of the establishments found was an out station of the American Presbyterian mission situated on
His Excellency Mr. E. Duclerc. President of the Council Ministree of Foreign Affairs. Paris.
Negenengue or Ningué Island. The "Marabout," it is true did not fire to the property of the Mission. But its hostile course around some of the native tribes, who rushed Ningué-Ningue, after the departure of the Gunboat, broke into the building of the Mission and plundered everything it contained. The members of the American Mission, who are represented by the Rev. Mr. Walker, had no opportunity of saving their property. They were not notified in advance by the French Authorities of any intended hostilities against the natives, and, to their knowledge, the inhabitants of Ningué-Ningué had committed no act which
could have given them reason to suppose that any such action was contemplated. It appears that some time before the destruction of this village, the Captain of the gunboat declared that there was no intention of proceeding against its people. It cannot, I think be claimed that the French Authorities are not responsible for the destruction of the Mission, as the natives would certainly never have resolved to violence and plunder if war had not been waged against them. During the 30 years the Mission has existed in Gabon, it has enjoyed the friendship of the natives, who were often left alone in charge
of its building and property.

In presence of these facts the American Mission of Gabon claims an indemnity of three thousand, five hundred francs (3500. frs) for the loss sustained in consequence of the action of the French authorities of the Colony, and I am instructed by my Government to lay this claim before you Excellency.

The amount of property destroyed is of no consequence to a government like France, but it is a large amount for poor clergymen who have exiled & themselves in a distant and uncivilized land for the cause of religion and morality.

At the time of this unpleasant incident, the Rev. Mr. Walker, speaking in the name of the Mission, applied to Captain Clerin. Commanding the Colony for the indemnity which is here claimed. But this officer, through replying that the claim would be submitted to the proper authority, seems to have misunderstood its real foundation and true character.

I cannot believe that the French Government, after a full examination of the facts, will adopt the defence outlined by Commandant Clérin that the mission station trespassed upon French territory, as such contention
would not effect the nature of the claim.

The simple question at issue seems to be whether the Mission station was pillaged by hostile natives in consequence of the destruction ordered by the French authorities, and if this destruction was called for by such an emergency of self defense as would prevent warning to non combattants

In the latter case the French Government will, doubtless, of its own accord, lender indemnification to these worthy men, who, since their establishment in Gabon. more than a quarter of a century ago - have held the most cordial
relations with the Colonial authorities, and have been a powerful adjunct to the civilizing and moral tendencies of the French rule on this part of the African Coast.

I avail myself of this occasion to renew the assurance of the distinguished consideration with which I have the honor to be,
Your Excellency's
Most obedient servant;
L.P. Morton
